content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a large, irregularly shaped section of tissue, heavily infiltrated by a tumor. The tumor appears glandular and is stained dark purple, indicating a high density of cells. The growth pattern is infiltrative and disorganized, characteristic of an adenocarcinoma. At the top, there are separate, smaller fragments of tissue which could be lymph nodes or parts of the resection margin. My initial impression is of a large, invasive colorectal adenocarcinoma.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is placed within the main body of the tumor. I would zoom into this area to closely examine the cytoarchitectural features of the carcinoma. This is essential to confirm the diagnosis, assess the tumor's grade (how differentiated the glands are), and identify any specific features like necrosis or particular cell types. This area seems representative of the invasive component of the tumor, making it ideal for detailed morphological evaluation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals malignant glands with significant architectural and cytological atypia. The glands are irregularly shaped, crowded, and lined by stratified, pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli. A key feature is the presence of abundant intraluminal necrotic debris, often termed 'dirty necrosis', which is highly characteristic of colorectal adenocarcinoma. The surrounding stroma is desmoplastic. My impression is that this is a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon.
